intro: Zanthoxylum arnottianum var. alatum, commonly known as the narrow-leaf prickly ash, is a deciduous shrub native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are alternate and typically have 5–9 pairs of leaflets. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers in clusters, followed by red, fleshy berries that are an important food source for wildlife. Its bark and leaves contain irritant compounds, making it a member of the Rutaceae family. The plant thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in woodland edges and stream banks.
